## Background

Oklahoma’s HB 1795 went into effect November 1, 2021 (Q2 FY 2022), reducing the number of offenses for which a license must be revoked (specific circumstances may still result in a revocation) while increasing the accessibility and affordability of provisional licenses. The bill imposes limitations on “failure to pay” license suspensions, with a key provision requiring the reduction to minimum payment plan for outstanding fines and fees (including but not limited to, provisional license fees, warrant fees, court costs or fees, and driver license reinstatements fees) from \$25 per month to \$5 per month. 

## Data and Methodology

This analysis uses Oklahoma court records sourced by OSCN and ODCR beginning January 1, 2022 (Q3 FY 2022) to estimate the impact of HB 1795 during a period of full implementation.
